moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4
comment:
This move is objectively much less strong than
4. 0-0, but it leads to the type of open game that
Marshall loved.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7
comment:
Developing the bishop and preparing to
castle. 5.. Nxe5 would lead to a disadvantage after
6. Re1, d5 7. Nxd4.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5
comment:
This pawn on the fifth rank cramps Black's king
position . On the other hand, Black may be able to
play f6 at some time and open a file for his rook. 
In some circumstances, the advanced pawn may even 
become weak and subject to attack. Unlike any other
chess piece, a pawn can not move backwards!

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4
comment:
There is no other square on the which this
knight could find security. At e5, it can be
protected by d4, and if White takes it e.p. d6, the
knight can recapture.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4
comment: Regaining the pawn.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4 O-O
comment:
Continuing his developement. 7..Nxe5?? would
lose a piece after 8. Re1, f5 9. f3.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4 O-O 8. Nf5 d5
comment:
This developing move protects his knight on
e5, and opens the diagonal of his queen bishop, which
now threatens White's knight.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4 O-O 8. Nf5 d5 9. Bxc6
comment:
The move that had usually been played here
was 9. Nxe7+, and this is probably best. After the
following exchanges, a position arises in which Black
has an advantage in developement, and also pressure
against White's king pawn. The situation is by no
means one sided, however; Black has some
vulnerability on the dark squares and his broken up
pawns on the queen side are weak.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4 O-O 8. Nf5 d5 9. Bxc6 bxc6 10. Nxe7+ Qxe7 11. Re1
comment:
This move which indirectly protects the king
pawn, is forced.  If 11. Bf4?, f6 12. f6, Rxf6 and
White already behind in developement, must lose more
time. If f3??, Qc5+ 12. Kh1, Nf2+ wins the exchange.
 If Black now plays 11. Qxe5??, 12. f3 wins a piece.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4 O-O 8. Nf5 d5 9. Bxc6 bxc6 10. Nxe7+ Qxe7 11. Re1 Qh4
comment:
This move is sometimes used as an example of
Lasker's well known skill in applying the
psychological element to chess. The objectively best
move here is 11..f6, which would open the king bishop 
file and allow Black to make use of his more active
pieces. However, Lasker feels that for this
particular opponent it will be psychologically more
difficult if he plays more aggressively and goes over
to the attack. The reason? Marshall was a player
who always strove for the initiative, and he was one
of the greatest attacking and combinative players of
all time. The defense was an uncomfortable and
unfamiliar role for him.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4 O-O 8. Nf5 d5 9. Bxc6 bxc6 10. Nxe7+ Qxe7 11. Re1 Qh4 12. Be3
comment:
Guarding his threatened f2.  If 12. f3 at
once was probably also good.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4 O-O 8. Nf5 d5 9. Bxc6 bxc6 10. Nxe7+ Qxe7 11. Re1 Qh4 12. Be3 f6 13. f3
comment: To drive the knight away from the attack.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4 O-O 8. Nf5 d5 9. Bxc6 bxc6 10. Nxe7+ Qxe7 11. Re1 Qh4 12. Be3 f6 13. f3 fxe5
comment: An elegant and most surprising sacrifice.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4 O-O 8. Nf5 d5 9. Bxc6 bxc6 10. Nxe7+ Qxe7 11. Re1 Qh4 12. Be3 f6 13. f3 fxe5 14. fxe4 d4 15. g3 Qf6 16. Bxd4 exd4 17. Rf1
comment:
Black's attack is to strong for White to
avoid simplification.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4 O-O 8. Nf5 d5 9. Bxc6 bxc6 10. Nxe7+ Qxe7 11. Re1 Qh4 12. Be3 f6 13. f3 fxe5 14. fxe4 d4 15. g3 Qf6 16. Bxd4 exd4 17. Rf1 Qxf1+ 18. Qxf1 Rxf1+ 19. Kxf1
comment:
Black appears to have only a shade of
advantage in this ending.  His bishop is better than
White's knight and his pieces will come into action
faster than White's. But as usual, his weak queenside
pawns affect the picture. Once White plays his
knight to b3, they will be under considerable
pressure. Now, however, Lasker with an almost 
magical charm finds away to obtain a decisive
advantage.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4 O-O 8. Nf5 d5 9. Bxc6 bxc6 10. Nxe7+ Qxe7 11. Re1 Qh4 12. Be3 f6 13. f3 fxe5 14. fxe4 d4 15. g3 Qf6 16. Bxd4 exd4 17. Rf1 Qxf1+ 18. Qxf1 Rxf1+ 19. Kxf1 Rb8
comment:
Instead of giving a bishop check on a6 or
h3, Black plays this surprising but far stronger
move. By forcing White's reply, Black denies White's
knight the crucial b3 square.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4 O-O 8. Nf5 d5 9. Bxc6 bxc6 10. Nxe7+ Qxe7 11. Re1 Qh4 12. Be3 f6 13. f3 fxe5 14. fxe4 d4 15. g3 Qf6 16. Bxd4 exd4 17. Rf1 Qxf1+ 18. Qxf1 Rxf1+ 19. Kxf1 Rb8 20. b3 Rb5
comment:
Still leaving his bishop at home,
Black moves his rook to an active position on the
fourth rank.  To his frustration, White now finds
that he can not develop his knight. If 21. Nd2, Rh5 
22. Kg1 Rc5  23. Rc1.  (If 23. Nc4, Bh3. ) 
23..Ba6 threatening Bd3, and White is helpless. To
avoid this, White is forced to advance his bishop pawn
to the forth rank, which will give Black a passed
queen pawn.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4 O-O 8. Nf5 d5 9. Bxc6 bxc6 10. Nxe7+ Qxe7 11. Re1 Qh4 12. Be3 f6 13. f3 fxe5 14. fxe4 d4 15. g3 Qf6 16. Bxd4 exd4 17. Rf1 Qxf1+ 18. Qxf1 Rxf1+ 19. Kxf1 Rb8 20. b3 Rb5 21. c4 Rh5
comment:
Forces White to take a move to protect
his queen rook pawn, thereby giving White no time to
play b4 to stop Black from playing c5.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4 O-O 8. Nf5 d5 9. Bxc6 bxc6 10. Nxe7+ Qxe7 11. Re1 Qh4 12. Be3 f6 13. f3 fxe5 14. fxe4 d4 15. g3 Qf6 16. Bxd4 exd4 17. Rf1 Qxf1+ 18. Qxf1 Rxf1+ 19. Kxf1 Rb8 20. b3 Rb5 21. c4 Rh5 22. Kg1 c5
comment: Now it is a protected passed pawn.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4 O-O 8. Nf5 d5 9. Bxc6 bxc6 10. Nxe7+ Qxe7 11. Re1 Qh4 12. Be3 f6 13. f3 fxe5 14. fxe4 d4 15. g3 Qf6 16. Bxd4 exd4 17. Rf1 Qxf1+ 18. Qxf1 Rxf1+ 19. Kxf1 Rb8 20. b3 Rb5 21. c4 Rh5 22. Kg1 c5 23. Nd2 Kf7
comment:
If Black delayed developing his king,
White would play 24. Rf1 and temporarily keep it out
of the game.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4 O-O 8. Nf5 d5 9. Bxc6 bxc6 10. Nxe7+ Qxe7 11. Re1 Qh4 12. Be3 f6 13. f3 fxe5 14. fxe4 d4 15. g3 Qf6 16. Bxd4 exd4 17. Rf1 Qxf1+ 18. Qxf1 Rxf1+ 19. Kxf1 Rb8 20. b3 Rb5 21. c4 Rh5 22. Kg1 c5 23. Nd2 Kf7 24. Rf1+
comment:
Whites only chance was 24. a3, attempting 
25. b4 to eliminate the protector of Black's passed
pawn.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4 O-O 8. Nf5 d5 9. Bxc6 bxc6 10. Nxe7+ Qxe7 11. Re1 Qh4 12. Be3 f6 13. f3 fxe5 14. fxe4 d4 15. g3 Qf6 16. Bxd4 exd4 17. Rf1 Qxf1+ 18. Qxf1 Rxf1+ 19. Kxf1 Rb8 20. b3 Rb5 21. c4 Rh5 22. Kg1 c5 23. Nd2 Kf7 24. Rf1+ Ke7 25. a3
comment: To late!

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4 O-O 8. Nf5 d5 9. Bxc6 bxc6 10. Nxe7+ Qxe7 11. Re1 Qh4 12. Be3 f6 13. f3 fxe5 14. fxe4 d4 15. g3 Qf6 16. Bxd4 exd4 17. Rf1 Qxf1+ 18. Qxf1 Rxf1+ 19. Kxf1 Rb8 20. b3 Rb5 21. c4 Rh5 22. Kg1 c5 23. Nd2 Kf7 24. Rf1+ Ke7 25. a3 Rh6
comment:
The fourth rank now occupied by his bishop
pawn, Black places his rook on the third rank, which
by reason of the removal of this same pawn is now the
most active rank.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4 O-O 8. Nf5 d5 9. Bxc6 bxc6 10. Nxe7+ Qxe7 11. Re1 Qh4 12. Be3 f6 13. f3 fxe5 14. fxe4 d4 15. g3 Qf6 16. Bxd4 exd4 17. Rf1 Qxf1+ 18. Qxf1 Rxf1+ 19. Kxf1 Rb8 20. b3 Rb5 21. c4 Rh5 22. Kg1 c5 23. Nd2 Kf7 24. Rf1+ Ke7 25. a3 Rh6 26. h4
comment:
So that his king will not be tied down to the
defense of this pawn. If 26. b4, Ra6 when 27. Ra1
can be answered by 27..b4 and White's rook pawn is
pinned.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4 O-O 8. Nf5 d5 9. Bxc6 bxc6 10. Nxe7+ Qxe7 11. Re1 Qh4 12. Be3 f6 13. f3 fxe5 14. fxe4 d4 15. g3 Qf6 16. Bxd4 exd4 17. Rf1 Qxf1+ 18. Qxf1 Rxf1+ 19. Kxf1 Rb8 20. b3 Rb5 21. c4 Rh5 22. Kg1 c5 23. Nd2 Kf7 24. Rf1+ Ke7 25. a3 Rh6 26. h4 Ra6
comment:
Forcing White either to tie his rook down to
this pawn's  defence, or play a4 and renounce the
possibility of b4 forever.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4 O-O 8. Nf5 d5 9. Bxc6 bxc6 10. Nxe7+ Qxe7 11. Re1 Qh4 12. Be3 f6 13. f3 fxe5 14. fxe4 d4 15. g3 Qf6 16. Bxd4 exd4 17. Rf1 Qxf1+ 18. Qxf1 Rxf1+ 19. Kxf1 Rb8 20. b3 Rb5 21. c4 Rh5 22. Kg1 c5 23. Nd2 Kf7 24. Rf1+ Ke7 25. a3 Rh6 26. h4 Ra6 27. Ra1 Bg4
comment: Finally developing the bishop.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4 O-O 8. Nf5 d5 9. Bxc6 bxc6 10. Nxe7+ Qxe7 11. Re1 Qh4 12. Be3 f6 13. f3 fxe5 14. fxe4 d4 15. g3 Qf6 16. Bxd4 exd4 17. Rf1 Qxf1+ 18. Qxf1 Rxf1+ 19. Kxf1 Rb8 20. b3 Rb5 21. c4 Rh5 22. Kg1 c5 23. Nd2 Kf7 24. Rf1+ Ke7 25. a3 Rh6 26. h4 Ra6 27. Ra1 Bg4 28. Kf2 Ke6
comment:
Bringing his king forward to help his
passed pawn.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4 O-O 8. Nf5 d5 9. Bxc6 bxc6 10. Nxe7+ Qxe7 11. Re1 Qh4 12. Be3 f6 13. f3 fxe5 14. fxe4 d4 15. g3 Qf6 16. Bxd4 exd4 17. Rf1 Qxf1+ 18. Qxf1 Rxf1+ 19. Kxf1 Rb8 20. b3 Rb5 21. c4 Rh5 22. Kg1 c5 23. Nd2 Kf7 24. Rf1+ Ke7 25. a3 Rh6 26. h4 Ra6 27. Ra1 Bg4 28. Kf2 Ke6 29. a4
comment:
There is nothing better. If 29. Nf3 to
prevent Black's king from reaching e5, then 29..Bxf3 
30. Kxf3 Ke5 followed by Rf6+ wins the king pawn. 
White, of course can not play Re1 without losing his 
queen rook pawn.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4 O-O 8. Nf5 d5 9. Bxc6 bxc6 10. Nxe7+ Qxe7 11. Re1 Qh4 12. Be3 f6 13. f3 fxe5 14. fxe4 d4 15. g3 Qf6 16. Bxd4 exd4 17. Rf1 Qxf1+ 18. Qxf1 Rxf1+ 19. Kxf1 Rb8 20. b3 Rb5 21. c4 Rh5 22. Kg1 c5 23. Nd2 Kf7 24. Rf1+ Ke7 25. a3 Rh6 26. h4 Ra6 27. Ra1 Bg4 28. Kf2 Ke6 29. a4 Ke5 30. Kg2 Rf6
comment:
Now that he need not worry about b4 by
White, Black  brings his rook to the open file.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4 O-O 8. Nf5 d5 9. Bxc6 bxc6 10. Nxe7+ Qxe7 11. Re1 Qh4 12. Be3 f6 13. f3 fxe5 14. fxe4 d4 15. g3 Qf6 16. Bxd4 exd4 17. Rf1 Qxf1+ 18. Qxf1 Rxf1+ 19. Kxf1 Rb8 20. b3 Rb5 21. c4 Rh5 22. Kg1 c5 23. Nd2 Kf7 24. Rf1+ Ke7 25. a3 Rh6 26. h4 Ra6 27. Ra1 Bg4 28. Kf2 Ke6 29. a4 Ke5 30. Kg2 Rf6 31. Re1 d3
comment:
With the Black king so close for
protection, this pawn can safely advance.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4 O-O 8. Nf5 d5 9. Bxc6 bxc6 10. Nxe7+ Qxe7 11. Re1 Qh4 12. Be3 f6 13. f3 fxe5 14. fxe4 d4 15. g3 Qf6 16. Bxd4 exd4 17. Rf1 Qxf1+ 18. Qxf1 Rxf1+ 19. Kxf1 Rb8 20. b3 Rb5 21. c4 Rh5 22. Kg1 c5 23. Nd2 Kf7 24. Rf1+ Ke7 25. a3 Rh6 26. h4 Ra6 27. Ra1 Bg4 28. Kf2 Ke6 29. a4 Ke5 30. Kg2 Rf6 31. Re1 d3 32. Rf1 Kd4
comment:
If now 33. Nf3+, Bxf3+ {{Not 33.. 
Kxe4??, 34. Re1+, Kf5 35. Re5+, Kg6 36. Rg5+ and
White wins the bishop! (Or 33.. Ke3?? 34. Re1#!) 
34. Rxf3 d2 {and this pawn can not be stopped from
queening.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4 O-O 8. Nf5 d5 9. Bxc6 bxc6 10. Nxe7+ Qxe7 11. Re1 Qh4 12. Be3 f6 13. f3 fxe5 14. fxe4 d4 15. g3 Qf6 16. Bxd4 exd4 17. Rf1 Qxf1+ 18. Qxf1 Rxf1+ 19. Kxf1 Rb8 20. b3 Rb5 21. c4 Rh5 22. Kg1 c5 23. Nd2 Kf7 24. Rf1+ Ke7 25. a3 Rh6 26. h4 Ra6 27. Ra1 Bg4 28. Kf2 Ke6 29. a4 Ke5 30. Kg2 Rf6 31. Re1 d3 32. Rf1 Kd4 33. Rxf6 gxf6 34. Kf2
comment:
At the moment, Whites K pawn is protected by
his knight, and his king keeps Black's king from
invading. But one of these pieces has no move! 
Black's next two moves mark time, so that White
exhausts his reserve of pawn moves.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4 O-O 8. Nf5 d5 9. Bxc6 bxc6 10. Nxe7+ Qxe7 11. Re1 Qh4 12. Be3 f6 13. f3 fxe5 14. fxe4 d4 15. g3 Qf6 16. Bxd4 exd4 17. Rf1 Qxf1+ 18. Qxf1 Rxf1+ 19. Kxf1 Rb8 20. b3 Rb5 21. c4 Rh5 22. Kg1 c5 23. Nd2 Kf7 24. Rf1+ Ke7 25. a3 Rh6 26. h4 Ra6 27. Ra1 Bg4 28. Kf2 Ke6 29. a4 Ke5 30. Kg2 Rf6 31. Re1 d3 32. Rf1 Kd4 33. Rxf6 gxf6 34. Kf2 c6 35. a5 a6 36. Nf1 Kxe4 37. Ke1 Be2 38. Nd2+ Ke3 39. Nb1 f5
comment:
So that White can not check on e4 after
Black's capture of White's king knight pawn.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4 exd4 5. O-O Be7 6. e5 Ne4 7. Nxd4 O-O 8. Nf5 d5 9. Bxc6 bxc6 10. Nxe7+ Qxe7 11. Re1 Qh4 12. Be3 f6 13. f3 fxe5 14. fxe4 d4 15. g3 Qf6 16. Bxd4 exd4 17. Rf1 Qxf1+ 18. Qxf1 Rxf1+ 19. Kxf1 Rb8 20. b3 Rb5 21. c4 Rh5 22. Kg1 c5 23. Nd2 Kf7 24. Rf1+ Ke7 25. a3 Rh6 26. h4 Ra6 27. Ra1 Bg4 28. Kf2 Ke6 29. a4 Ke5 30. Kg2 Rf6 31. Re1 d3 32. Rf1 Kd4 33. Rxf6 gxf6 34. Kf2 c6 35. a5 a6 36. Nf1 Kxe4 37. Ke1 Be2 38. Nd2+ Ke3 39. Nb1 f5 40. Nd2 h5 41. Nb1 Kf3 42. Nc3 Kxg3 43. Na4 f4 44. Nxc5 f3 45. Ne4+ Kf4 46. Nd6 c5
comment:
If now 47. Nb7 or any other knight move,
47.. Ke3 followed by mate with either pawn.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d4
comment:
This move is objectively much less strong than
4. 0-0, but it leads to the type of open game that
Marshall loved.
